awd_titl_txt: Protein Folding and Embryogenesis in Antarctic Fishes: A Comparative Approach to Environmental Stress
awd_abstract_narration:
Since the advent of Antarctic continental glaciation, the opening of the Drake Passage between South America and the Antarctic Peninsula, and the onset of cooling of the Southern Ocean ~40-25 million years ago, evolution of the Antarctic marine biota has been driven by the development of extreme cold temperatures.  As circum-Antarctic coastal temperatures declined during this period from ~20°C to the modern ?1.9 to +2.0°C (reached ~8-10 million years ago), the psychrophilic (cold-loving) ectotherms of the Southern Ocean evolved compensatory molecular, cellular, and physiological traits that enabled them to maintain normal metabolic function at cold temperatures.  Today, these organisms are threatened by rapid warming of the Southern Ocean over periods measured in centuries (as much as 5°C/100 yr), a timeframe so short that re-adaptation and/or acclimatization to the ?new warm? may not be possible.  Thus, the long-term goals of this research project are: 1) to understand the biochemical and physiological capacities of the embryos of Antarctic notothenioid fish to resist or compensate for rapid oceanic warming; and 2) to assess the genetic toolkit available to support the acclimatization and adaptation of Antarctic notothenioid embryos to their warming habitat.  The specific aims of this work are: 1) to determine the capacity of the chaperonin complex of notothenioid fishes to assist protein folding at temperatures between ?4 and +20°C; and 2) to evaluate the genetic responses of notothenioid embryos, measured as global differential gene transcription, to temperature challenge, with ?1.9°C as the ?normal? control and +4 and +10°C as high temperature insults.
The physiology of embryonic development of marine stenotherms under future climate change scenarios is an important but understudied problem.  This project will provide valuable insights into the capacity of Antarctic fish embryos to acclimatize and adapt to plausible climate change scenarios by examining multiple levels of biological organization, from the biochemical to the organismal.  The results should also be broadly applicable to understanding the impact of global warming on marine biota worldwide.  The research will also introduce graduate and REU undergraduate students to state-of-the-art biochemical, cellular, and molecular-biological research relevant to ecological and environmental issues of the Antarctic marine ecosystem.

por.por_cntn:
Since the advent of Antarctic continental glaciation, the opening of the Drake Passage between South America and the Antarctic Peninsula, and the onset of cooling of the Southern Ocean 40-25 million years ago, evolution of Antarctic fishes and other marine ectotherms (whose body temperatures conform to environmental temperature) has been driven by the development of extreme cold temperatures. As circum-Antarctic coastal temperatures declined during this period from +20 C to the modern -1.9 to +2 C, the fish fauna, which largely belongs to the teleost sub-order Notothenioidei, adapted by evolution of compensatory molecular, cellular, and physiological traits that enabled them to maintain normal metabolic function. Today, these fishes are threatened by rapid warming of the Southern Ocean over periods measured in centuries (as much as 5 C/100 yr), a timeframe so short that re-adaptation and/or acclimatization to the "new warm" may not be possible.

The long-term goals of this research project were: 1) to understand the biochemical and physiological capacities of Antarctic notothenioid fishes to resist or compensate for rapid oceanic warming; 2) to assess the genetic "toolkit" available to support the acclimatization and adaptation of Antarctic fish embryos to their warming habitat; and 3) to evaluate the evolutionary mechanisms that have shaped the genomes of these fishes. Goal 1 was focused on the functional properties of the cellular protein-folding machine, the chaperonin CCT, evaluated at temperatures between -4 and +20 C. Goal 2 was explored by subjecting embryos of the bullhead notothen to thermal challenge, with -1.9 C as the control and +4 C as the "high" temperature insult, followed by analysis of differential gene transcription (in progress). The third goal was investigated by evaluating genomes and transcriptomes from red-blooded notothens and "white-blooded" (i.e., lacking red blood cells) icefishes.

Significant scientific outcomes of this project are described in five major publications:

  1. Goal 1: Cuellar et al. [(2014) Assisted protein folding at low temperature: evolutionary adaptation of the Antarctic fish chaperonin CCT and its client proteins. Biology Open 3, 261-270] showed that the cellular gatekeeper of protein homeostasis, CCT, remains functional at temperatures as high as +5-10 C, well above the normal temperatures currently experienced by Antarctic fishes. This result suggests that, at current rates of Southern Ocean warming, the cellular proteome of these fishes is likely to be resilient to thermal perturbation for several centuries.
  2. Goal 2: Postlethwait et al. [(2016) Embryogenesis and early skeletogenesis in the Antarctic bullhead notothen, Notothenia coriiceps. Developmental Dynamics, in press] described embryonic development of the bullhead notothen, which is an important intermediate component of the Southern Ocean food web, at -1 to +1 C as part of their work on the potential impacts of climate change on Antarctic fishes. Their detailed staging series from fertilization through hatching sets the stage for ongoing and future molecular analyses of thermal perturbation of embryonic development and larval recruitment.
  3. Goal 3: Shin et al. [(2014) The genome sequence of the Antarctic bullhead notothen reveals evolutionary adaptations to a cold environment. Genome Biology 15, 468] published the first genome of an Antarctic notothenioid fish. Mining of the genome data revealed that genes encoding mitochondrial proteins have evolved rapidly to preserve efficient cellular respiration at cold temperatures. Furthermore, the near universal loss of the "classical" heat-shock response (HSR) by Antarctic fishes was shown to result fom mutation of the heat-shock transcription factor HSF1, which converts the normally heat-inducible HSR to an "always on" state. This first reference genome will facilitate future comparative studies of the notothenioid adaptive radiation.
  4. Goal 3: Desvignes et al. [(2016) Genomic conservation of erythropoietic microRNAs (erythromiRs) in white-blooded Antarctic icefish. Marine Genomics, in press] demonstrated that the loss of red blood cells and hemoglobin by the Antarctic icefishes was not caused by loss of important erythroid-regulating microRNAs from icefish genomes. Rather, conservation and expression of all known erythromiR genes by icefishes indicates that they may play important roles in other cells and tissues.
  5. Goal 3: Hu et al. [(2016) Evolution in an extreme environment: developmental biases and phenotypic integration in the adaptive radiation of Antarctic notothenioids. BMC Evolutionary Biology 16, 142] used a 3D-morphometrics approach to investigate patterns of variation in the craniofacial skeletons of notothenioid fishes. They found that variation in head shape is best explained by divergent selection based on foraging niche. They also documented an accelerated rate of craniofacial evolution in the icefishes, which was linked to high levels of morphological integration and traceable to shifts in early developmental patterning mechanisms. Icefishes stand out as a rare example of increased trait integration facilitating, rather than constraining, evolutionary potential.

Throughout this project, the Principal Investigator has mentored high school, undergraduate, and graduate students on research projects at Northeastern University and at Palmer Station, Antarctica. He has also conducted numerous outreach activities to introduce lay audiences to the importance of polar research.
